failure_modes.description: Thinking you're better than you are
failure_modes.real_world_case: 90% of drivers think they're above average.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: If you're never wrong, you're not tracking

failure_modes.real_world_case: Sellers wanting 2x what buyers will pay.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Ownership premium is typically 2-3x

failure_modes.description: Taking credit for success, blaming others for failure
failure_modes.real_world_case: CEOs crediting themselves in good times, blaming economy in bad.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Apply same standards to success and failure

failure_modes.description: Not knowing what you don't know
failure_modes.real_world_case: Dunning-Kruger effect - incompetent don't know they're incompetent.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Everyone has 3-5 major blind spots

failure_modes.description: Choosing comparisons that make you look good
failure_modes.real_world_case: Comparing to worst performers, not best.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Compare to top 10%, not bottom 50%

failure_modes.real_world_case: Sydney Opera House: 4 years planned, 16 years actual.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Projects typically take 2-3x planned time

failure_modes.real_world_case: Startup founders ignoring 90% failure rate.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Your project is probably not special

failure_modes.real_world_case: First-mover advantage often illusory.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Competitors will respond within 6-12 months

failure_modes.real_world_case: Illusion of control in random events.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: You control less than you think

failure_modes.real_world_case: Studying successful entrepreneurs, ignoring failures.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: For every success story, there are 10-100 failures

failure_modes.description: Avoiding action to avoid potential loss
failure_modes.real_world_case: Not selling losing positions, hoping for recovery.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Losses feel 2x worse than equivalent gains

failure_modes.real_world_case: Concorde fallacy - continuing failed project.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Sunk costs are sunk - only future matters

failure_modes.real_world_case: Panic selling after market dip.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Near-misses are normal, not signals

failure_modes.real_world_case: Companies fighting for declining markets.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Defense should be proportional to value

failure_modes.real_world_case: Lawsuits that cost more than the loss.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Revenge typically costs more than original loss

failure_modes.real_world_case: Dot-com bubble - everyone buying because everyone buying.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: When everyone agrees, be suspicious

failure_modes.real_world_case: No one asking questions in meetings.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: If no one's questioning, no one's thinking

failure_modes.real_world_case: Bystander effect - no one helps because no one helps.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: In uncertainty, social proof is least reliable

failure_modes.real_world_case: Following analyst recommendations blindly.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Experts are wrong 30-40% on complex issues

failure_modes.real_world_case: Fake reviews, astroturfing.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: 10-30% of online reviews are fake

failure_modes.description: Judging by contrast, not absolute value
failure_modes.real_world_case: Expensive item seems cheap after seeing more expensive one.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Anchors can shift judgments by 50%+

failure_modes.real_world_case: Slowly declining business not noticed until crisis.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: 1% daily decline = 97% annual decline

failure_modes.real_world_case: Decoy pricing making expensive option seem reasonable.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Decoys can shift choice by 30-50%

failure_modes.description: Spending more because others spend more
failure_modes.real_world_case: Keeping up with wealthy neighbors.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Reference group determines spending more than income

failure_modes.real_world_case: Good quarter after bad seems great, even if mediocre.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Judge against long-term average, not recent past

failure_modes.real_world_case: Panic selling during market crashes.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Stress reduces decision quality by 30-50%

failure_modes.real_world_case: Pilots fixating on one instrument in emergency.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Stress narrows attention by 50%+

failure_modes.real_world_case: Trained responses overriding better judgment.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Under stress, habits dominate deliberation

failure_modes.real_world_case: Signing bad deals under time pressure.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Artificial urgency is manipulation signal

failure_modes.real_world_case: Burnout affecting all decisions.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Chronic stress reduces cognitive function 20-40%

failure_modes.real_world_case: Overreacting to recent market moves.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Recent events are overweighted 3-5x

failure_modes.real_world_case: Fear of plane crashes vs car accidents.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Vivid events overweighted 10x+ vs statistics

failure_modes.real_world_case: Overestimating crime because of news coverage.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: News coverage ≠ actual frequency

failure_modes.real_world_case: Judging market by own portfolio performance.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Personal experience is tiny, biased sample

failure_modes.real_world_case: Overestimating risks that are easy to imagine.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Easy to recall ≠ likely to occur

failure_modes.real_world_case: Milgram experiment - shocking others on authority.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: 65% will follow authority to harm others

failure_modes.description: Assuming expertise in one area transfers
failure_modes.real_world_case: Celebrity endorsements outside expertise.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Expertise doesn't transfer across domains

failure_modes.real_world_case: Trusting people in suits, uniforms.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Symbols are easily faked

failure_modes.real_world_case: Not challenging boss even when wrong.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Hierarchy silences 50%+ of valid concerns

failure_modes.real_world_case: Following old investment wisdom in new markets.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Authority advice has half-life of 5-10 years

failure_modes.real_world_case: Jargon-filled reports hiding lack of substance.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: If you can't explain simply, you don't understand

failure_modes.real_world_case: Meetings that produce no decisions.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: 50%+ of meeting time is often waste

failure_modes.real_world_case: Academic papers with no practical value.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Credentials don't guarantee value

failure_modes.real_world_case: Consultants hiding behind jargon.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Complexity often hides lack of substance

failure_modes.description: Fooling yourself with your own nonsense
failure_modes.real_world_case: Rationalizing bad decisions with complex logic.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: If explanation is complex, it's probably wrong

failure_modes.real_world_case: Copy machine experiment - 'because I need to' worked.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Any reason increases compliance 50%+

failure_modes.real_world_case: Sales pitches with pseudo-reasons.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Reasons can be manufactured to manipulate

failure_modes.real_world_case: Believing explanations without evidence.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Verify reasons, don't just accept them

failure_modes.description: More reasons = more convincing, regardless of quality
failure_modes.real_world_case: Long lists of weak reasons seeming strong.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: One strong reason > ten weak reasons

failure_modes.description: Accepting stated reason, missing actual reason
failure_modes.real_world_case: Stated reasons for decisions hiding real motivations.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Stated reasons often differ from actual reasons
